Force expired on April 1, and the Navy
has been' operating its program under
authority of annual appropriation bills.
Under the new bill, “educational op¬
portunities may be provided by means
of service operated or sponsored cor¬
respondence courses, locally conducted
academic classes, or such facilities as
may be made available by those coop¬
erating civilian educational institutions
as may be recognized as accredited by
the Office of Education. . . or by the
departments of education of the respec¬
tive states.” Tuition assistance to serv¬
ice personnel is authorized in amounts
not exceeding “50 per centum of such
tuition fees charged by cooperating civil¬
ian educational institutions in the case
of officer personnel or 75 per centum
of such tuition fees in the case of en¬
listed personnel.”
The greatest danger to this legislation
is lack of interest rather than oppo¬
sition in Congress. Institutions de¬
siring early action on the bill should
communicate with Senator Leverett
Saltonstall, chairman of the Committee
on Armed Services of the Senate, and
Representative Dewey Short, chairman of
the Committee on Armed Services of the
House . . .
S 971, which provides that postal rates
for film and other audio-visual mate¬
rials for instructional use by schools and
colleges shall be the same as those for
books, was passed by the Senate on May
21 and is pending in the House as HR
1939. This legislation was endorsed by
the Committee on Relationships at its
meeting on May 29, and its action has
been communicated to the House Com¬
mittee on Post Office and Civil Service.
That committee is expected to report
the bill to the floor soon, following hear¬
ings scheduled to open on June 10.
Those interested should write their own
Representatives in the House.
*From Higher Education, June 12, 1953.
Purdue Center
Purdue University is planning for con¬
struction of a “miniature” steel mill
on the 168-acre campus of the Center in
Hammond, Indiana.
The proposed 152 by 200-foot brick
building will be a two-story “industrial
research institute” structure that will
cost an estimated $600,000. It will be
used for additional classrooms and for
an inland steel company research labora¬
tory.
D. Mack Easton
Professor D. Mack Easton has been
appointed the new Dean of Extension
at the University of Colorado to succeed
W. M. Campbell, who writes: “You
will find Mr. Easton a valuable mem¬
ber of the NUEA. He is exceptional
as a presiding officer and in leading
discussion. I predict for him a suc¬
cessful administration as Dean of Ex¬
tension. I am happy to see him take
,""ir Extension at the University ***
Colorado. We have worked together
for several years to strengthen the posi¬
tion of Extension in Colorado, and I
predict that our efforts will produce
results under Mack’s direction.
“Both Easton and I worked with the
Committee of the Senate on Utiliza¬
tion of University Resources. The re¬
port of this Committee which provides
for some rather far-reaching changes in
the administration of Extension was ap¬
proved unanimously last month. It
calls for the coordination of all Ex¬
tension activities under a committee of
the deans of which the Dean of Exten¬
sion will be chairman. It also calls for
more financial support to Extension and
a considerable, though gradual, expan¬
sion of Extension Services.
“I appreciate very much the connection
I have had with the NUEA as Director
here and hope to continue to serve
the cause in the future.”
Mr. Easton has been Director of the
University’s Bureau of State and Com¬
munity Service since 1944. He will suc¬
ceed Mr. Campbell who will retire July
1 after 30 years with the University.
Mr. Campbell was the “one man staff”
of the Bureau of Class Instruction, now
one of the largest bureaus of the Divi¬
sion, when he joined the University in
1923. In mid-1951 he was appointed
the Division Director.
In announcing Dean Easton’s appoint¬
ment, the regents commented that nu¬
merous outstanding candidates from out¬
side the state had been considered be¬
fore the final selection. Mr. Easton has
been with the University since 1929, be¬
ing first associated with the Speech
Department. He was on leave in
1942-43 to be director of War Services
for the State of Colorado and 1951-52
to be Dean of the Staff College of the
Federal Civil Defense Administration,
cum laude from Huron College, Huron,
South Dakota, and a M.A. from Cornell
University, Ithaca, New York.
Howard Walker
Thomas Howard Walker will become
director of University Extension at the
University of Kansas effective Septem¬
ber 1.
Walker, a 39-year-old Indianan, is now
director of the Mobile center of the Uni¬
versity of Alabama. Before going south
to organize the Mobile center three years
ago he was for three years director of
the Richmond center of Indiana Uni¬
versity.
The 6’ 4” Walker will receive the doc¬
torate degree this fall from Indiana Uni¬
versity, where he earned an M.S. degree
in 1947. He received the A.B. degree
in 1938 from Earlham College, Rich¬
mond, Indiana, having majored in Eng¬
lish and physical education. Walker’s
teaching experience spans rural, junior
and senior high schools. At Indiana
University he was supervisor of the test¬
ing bureau and later assistant to the
director of Veterans’ affairs while tak¬
ing graduate work.
Dr. Frank T. Stockton, dean of Uni¬
versity Extension since 1947, will become
director of special projects in the di¬
vision of University Extension. Dean
Stockton has served one year beyond
the customary retirement age for ad¬
ministrators pending the selection of a
successor.
“Because of the great growth in vol¬
ume and scope of extension work dur¬
ing Dean Stockton’s administration, we
have most carefully sought a successor,”
Chancellor Murphy of Kansas said. “In
Mr. Walker we are gaining a tested ad¬
ministrator with the breadth of personal
interests and experience to provide
Kansas citizens with the educational
services they are increasingly asking of
our extension program.”
Illinois
The 6th annual conference on adult
education is scheduled for June 30th
at Urbana on the campus of the Uni¬
versity. The principal address is by
Dean Robert B. Browne on “Developing
Adult Educators.” The conference is
sponsored by the Illinois Adult Educa¬
tion Association and the Summer Ses¬
sion of the University.
